bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 27, 1924

div1.p: Connor reports on mosquito breeding and the need to introduce fish for mosquito control. He notes that there is public pressure on the government for mosquito reduction.

May 27, 1924.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
While in British Guiana I made it a special point
to look for Aedes Aegypti in mud puddles but in no instance did I
succeed in finding them. This confirms what Doctor Wise found some
years ago in the same Colony and more recently by Mr. Cleare, Government
Entomologist.

There is no need for the stegomyia aegypti to seek
breeding in a mud puddle in British Guiana as receptacles holding clean
water are available every where even on the Sugar estates. With family of
means their water is stowed in large surface cisterns similar to those
in use at New Orleans. About 52% of the 300 hundred premises inspected
were infested with ‘stegs’.

It seems strange, but never-the-less true, that the
value of fish have not been appreciated here by the medical authorities
and by failure here it follows that the public have not been enligthened.

In the smaller towns I found several blacks using fish
in their water barrels not as a protection aginst “wigglers” but to de-
termine the suitability of the water for drinking purposes which is a
relic from Africa where one tribe tries to destroy the other by poisoning
the water supply and which they test by placing a fish in it, which if
it lives everything is o.k. otherwise not.

The East Indian coolies were also using fish with the
thought of keeping all insects out and they were successful.

There would no trouble to bring fish into general use
in this Colony if proper propaganda were made and as the varities of
fishes arexalmost unlimited good results would sure to follow.

We could not find any definite evidence of recent
yellow fever in the Colony but everything indicates that the infection has been
present ata later date than is officially reported (1909) It would not be-
come endemic as immigration into the Colony has practically ceased.

The Medical Service, the present one, has never seen a case of
Schistomiasis Mansoni but of course this does mean that it is not
present as the post-mortems are not carefully made due to the great
amount of work placed on each officer, for instance, at the time of
our visit the Bacteriologist and Pathologist was also Acting Quarantine
Officer (Boarding Vessels) also radiologist and attempting to conduct a
study of Filariasis which is very prevelent here and increasing at a
rather alarming rate.

The cadavers are sent to the autposy room where a boys opens them and
and lays out the organs on a table for the Doctor to view, these are
not generally opened therefore it is easy to see that bilharzia might
get by them.

The hope for Georgetown from a mosquito standpoint lies in the fact
that there is a growing public opinion pressing the Government to under
take a general mosquito reduction and the alarming increase of filariasis
is interesting the planter in mosquito reduction. The Government has approv
ed a plan for a modern system of sewerage disposl which work is already
underway, also an elaborate scheme for surface drainage independent of the
present tidal drains.

I think that as a result of our visit there will fulls develop an
interest in fish as larvae consumers and that the surface cisterns in
place of being covered, really partially covered, as hereto fore, will be fished
with good results.

I will write you again from this Colony, so far Dengue is admitted and
also a confusion in the minds of some physicians as to whether some of
the so-called cases of dengue were not really mild yellow fever. OI am
sorry that Doctor Flu is not here, his report of the 1908 and 09 cases
are intensely interesting but I wonder why he did not note Faget's sign.

During 1923 and part 1924 several cases of Weil's disease were reported
in Paramaribo. Dr. Pothier hopes to get some of the survivors and try
the reaction, both organisms.
With continued good wishes, I am
div1.closer: Most sincerely yours, M E Connor Please commend me to Miss Laura.
